The long-awaited Grand Theft Auto 6 is finally on the horizon, and fans are gearing up for launch day. While the game promises endless ways to build your coffers on-screen, you can start stacking savings in real life, too. The right credit card can help you cut costs on the game, upgrades and even the console you’ll play it on.

GTA 6 is slated for release on May 26, 2026, after Rockstar Games pushed back the initial release date. The delay, however, means that gamers will have plenty of time to prepare a game plan.

Rockstar Games offers GTA+, a paid subscription that offers gamers resources and in-game currency. Currently, GTA+ costs $7.99 per month, but gives users an instant leg up in the game, with a revenue stream of GTA$500,000 deposited monthly to your Maze Bank account, member-only Shark cards with a 15% GTA$ bonus, as well as vanity perks, such as access to:

While the game is not play to win, these resources will set you ahead of the curve, without having to spend hours grinding to earn in-game currency for cars and clothes. Time, after all, is a resource that money can’t buy. The best credit cards for gamers can help you get to the top with less effort while earning rewards along the way.

The Prime Visa offers a $150 Amazon gift card upon approval with an eligible Prime membership, which you can use to pay off a year and a half’s worth of GTA+. What’s more, users earn 5% back on purchases at Amazon.com, Amazon Fresh, Whole Foods Market and on Chase Travel purchases with an eligible Prime membership, unlimited 2% back at gas stations, restaurants and on local transit and commuting (including rideshare), and unlimited 1% back on other purchases.

Keep in mind, you need to have an Amazon Prime membership to qualify, but the card has no annual fee.

For a $0 annual fee, the Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card (rates & fees) offers a flat and uncapped 2% cash rewards on purchases.

Cardholders can earn $200 cash rewards bonus after spending $500 in purchases in the first 3 months. You can use that offer toward 25 months’ worth of GTA+, while the flat rate earning potential applies across the board for things like consoles and digital purchases.

If you’re a hardcore PlayStation gamer, the PlayStation® Visa® Credit Card* might make sense for you, especially as cardholders earn 5 points per dollar spent on qualifying PlayStation and Sony products when you shop directly, in store or at authorized retailers. Earn 3 points for every dollar spent on cable, internet and streaming subscriptions, 2 points on dining and restaurants and 1 point for every $1 spent on all other eligible purchases.

Points earned with purchases on the PlayStation card can be redeemed for digital gift cards and PlayStation store cards.

Plus, it offers a handful of practical extras, including a welcome offer, an intro APR and cellphone insurance. With several 2% cash-back credit cards available today, it’s essential to dig through the details to find the best one for you. How does the Active Cash stack up and is it worth considering? We’ve examined the details and compared options to help you make an informed decision.

When You Should Consider the Wells Fargo Active Cash
Here’s what we like most about the Wells Fargo Active Cash card.
You Want a Cash-Back Card That Keeps Things Simple
If you value simplicity, the Wells Fargo Active Cash offers just that with rewards that are straightforward to earn and redeem. Cardholders earn an unlimited 2% cash rewards on purchases. Rewards do not expire as long as the account is open.
The Wells Fargo Active Cash also comes with a first-year welcome offer: Earn a $200 cash rewards bonus after spending $500 in purchases in the first 3 months.
You can redeem your Wells Fargo Rewards for:
- Cash
- Offsetting purchases
- Gift cards
- Charitable donations
Rewards may also be pooled with eligible Wells Fargo points-earnings cards, which include the Wells Fargo Autograph® Card (rates & fees) and the Wells Fargo Autograph Journey℠ Card (rates & fees). When you combine your earnings, you can optionally take advantage of Wells Fargo’s travel transfer partners to look for ways to increase the value of your points.
You Appreciate the Wells Fargo Active Cash’s Extra Benefits
No annual fee can sometimes be synonymous with no extra benefits, but the Active Cash is an outlier. It comes with the following protections and perks:
- Cellphone protection. Get up to $600 of cellphone protection against damage or theft. Subject to a $25 deductible.
- Auto rental collision damage waiver. Get secondary insurance coverage up to $50,000 to protect against damage or theft to your rental car.
- Visa Signature Concierge. Get 24/7, 365-day phone support for travel and entertainment needs.
- Visa Signature Luxury Hotel Collection. Get extra perks and benefits at a worldwide collection of properties.
- Zero liability protection. Cardholders are protected against unauthorized charges if they’re reported promptly.
When You Shouldn’t Consider the Active Cash Card
There’s no one-size-fits-all credit card, and what works for one person may not make sense for another. Some reasons you may want to pass on the Wells Fargo Active Cash include:
You Need a Lengthier Intro APR Offer
A card that earns rewards, has no annual fee and offers an introductory APR on purchases is quite the trifecta. However, the Active Cash falls short regarding its introductory APR period length compared to other cards on the market. You’ll get a 0% intro APR for 12 months from account opening on purchases and qualifying balance transfers, then a 19.24%, 24.24%, or 29.24% variable APR applies. Balance transfers made within 120 days qualify for the intro rate and fee of 3% (min. $5) then a fee of up to 5% (min. $5) applies. If you need a longer intro APR period, the Active Cash may not be right for you.
You Want To Maximize Specific Spending Categories
The flat-rate cash rewards structure of the Active Cash Card is uncomplicated, but it doesn’t offer the opportunity to earn more in specific spending categories. If a significant portion of your budget goes toward groceries, dining or travel, you could benefit more from a card offering bonus rewards in those areas. Some cards offer 5% or more cash back for everyday categories like gas or groceries.
You’re Looking for Travel Benefits or Premium Perks
The Active Cash Card is designed for straightforward cash rewards but doesn’t cater to frequent travelers or those seeking premium features. Unlike travel-focused cards, it lacks benefits such as trip cancellation or interruption insurance and charges foreign transaction fees.
These perks can significantly enhance your travel experience and save you money abroad. For globetrotters or those who want luxury perks, the Active Cash may feel underwhelming compared to travel cards that prioritize these advantages.
Are You Eligible for the Wells Fargo Active Cash Card?
Wells Fargo doesn’t specify a credit score required for approval, but some basic criteria can help determine your eligibility for the Active Cash card.
- Credit score. In general, rewards cards require good credit (FICO Score of 670 or higher), though a score alone will not guarantee approval for any card, including the Wells Fargo Active Cash.
- Account history. Wells Fargo may limit your ability to be approved for a credit card if you opened another Wells Fargo card within the last six months.
- Prior card membership. If you’ve held a Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card within the last 48 months (even if that account is closed and has no balance), Wells Fargo may approve you for a new card but could withhold the welcome bonus or intro APR offer.
Wells Fargo Active Cash Rewards Potential
We used data from multiple government agencies to estimate a typical household’s spending. Our research showed that a household earning in the 70th percentile in 2025 brings in $127,200 and charges $40,398 to credit cards. Putting all of this spending on the Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card would result in $807.96 cash back annually once redeemed. Substitute your spending amounts to calculate your individual anticipated earnings.
How To Maximize Wells Fargo Active Cash
- Capitalize on the welcome offer. If you have a significant upcoming expense, time it to coincide with the new cardholder welcome offer: $200 cash rewards bonus after spending $500 in purchases in the first 3 months.
- Use the card for recurring monthly expenses. You can take advantage of the card’s unlimited 2% cash rewards on purchases when using it for recurring monthly expenses. Just don’t forget to pay off your balance each month to avoid interest charges and ultimately negate your rewards.
- Pair it with a Wells Fargo travel card. By combining the Active Cash with a Wells Fargo points-based card like the Wells Fargo Autograph® Card or Wells Fargo Autograph Journey℠ Card you’ll not only get access to more bonus categories but you’ll gain the ability to transfer your rewards to any of Wells Fargo’s airline or hotel travel partners.

How the Wells Fargo Active Cash Card Stacks Up
Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card vs. Citi Double Cash® Card
The Citi Double Cash® Card is similar to the Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card with no annual fee and earning 2% cash back on all purchases—1% when purchases are made and another 1% when they’re paid off, and earn 5% total cash back on hotel, car rentals and attractions booked with Citi Travel.
Those needing a lengthier intro period for balance transfers should choose the Citi Double Cash® Card as you’ll get a 0% intro APR on balance transfers for 18 months. After that, the standard variable APR will be 18.24% to 28.24%, based on creditworthiness. An intro balance transfer fee of either $5 or 3%, whichever is greater, applies to transfers completed within the first 4 months of account opening. After that, the fee will be 5% of each transfer (minimum $5).
The Active Cash is better if you want an intro APR for purchases, though, since the Double Cash doesn’t offer that. The Citi Double Cash also doesn’t include cellphone protection like the Wells Fargo Active Cash. However, you can transfer your points to many of Citi’s travel loyalty partners.
For a deeper comparison, look into more details in our showdown of the Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card vs. Citi Double Cash® Card.
Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card vs. Chase Freedom Unlimited®
It might be less complex, but the Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card may also be less rewarding than the Chase Freedom Unlimited®. With the Freedom Unlimited, you can earn 5% cash back on travel purchased through Chase Travel℠, 3% cash back on eligible dining and drugstores and 1.5% on all other purchases. The Chase Freedom Unlimited® also offers more perks like purchase protection, extended warranty coverage and travel protections.
Both cards have similar welcome bonuses, with the Freedom Unlimited new cardholders earn $200 cash back after spending $500 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening.
Our full comparison of the Chase Freedom Unlimited vs. Wells Fargo Active Cash has deeper insight into which card might be right for you.
Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card vs. Discover it® Cash Back
The Discover it® Cash Back has no annual fee and earns excellent bonus rewards in quarterly rotating categories. More effort is required to track these potential bonus rewards than the Active Cash’s simple 2% rewards, but the extra earnings could be worth it. You’ll earn 5% cash back on everyday purchases at different places each quarter up to a quarterly maximum when activated. Plus, earn unlimited 1% cash back on all other purchases. The Discover it® Cash Back doesn’t offer comparable benefits to the Active Cash, like travel and cellphone protections.
Since these cards differ in how they earn rewards, consider pairing them together. You can use the Discover it® Cash Back for spending in the bonus categories until you hit the quarterly cap and use the Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card for all other purchases.
Alternatives to the Wells Fargo Active Cash Card
Is the Wells Fargo Active Cash Card for You?
The Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card is a well-rounded card thanks to its unlimited 2% cash rewards on purchases, intro APR and no annual fee. The Active Cash can also be an excellent complementary card to one that earns elevated rewards for spending in specific categories. This will ensure your minimum earning rate on all purchases is double the base rate of most cards.
Wells Fargo Active Cash Review Methodology
The Wells Fargo Active Cash® Card was graded according to Forbes Advisor’s rankings methodology for cash-back cards. We consider a variety of criteria when assigning a rating to cash-back cards, including:
- Estimated annual earnings
- Annual fees
- Welcome bonus offers
- Intro APR offers
- Regular APR
- Additional cardholder benefits
We give greater weight to the card features we believe cardholders will use most frequently. These factors combine to generate a star rating for each card.

What credit score is needed for the Wells Fargo Active Cash Card?
Wells Fargo does not disclose the required credit score for the Active Cash, but generally, applicants will need a good or better credit score of about 670 or above. No credit score guarantees approval.

The easiest way to get a Wells Fargo credit card is to find and submit an application at the issuer’s website. Applications generally consist of personal and financial information, including name, date of birth, address, and housing and employment status. Approved applicants will be notified online and receive a card in the mail.
How do you redeem Wells Fargo Active Cash rewards?
Wells Fargo Active Cash rewards can be redeemed through your online account or mobile app. You’ll see several redemption options, such as offsetting posted transactions as little as $1 or depositing your cash back into a qualifying Wells Fargo account, such as a checking account or mortgage, in $25 increments. You can also withdraw rewards as cash from an ATM in $20 increments or redeem them for gift cards.

The Active Cash application asks for details including your full name, birth date, address, Social Security number, information on assets, housing payments and annual income.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)
Should I use a credit card for gaming purchases?
Using a credit card for your gaming purchases can be a good idea if the card earns rewards that you can use and if there are purchase protections or extended warranty coverage to protect what you buy. But, if you typically carry a balance, any rewards or other benefits will be negated by the double-digit interest rate you’ll accumulate on the card.
What kind of streaming and entertainment purchases count as a bonus category?
That will depend on the card and how the issuer classifies streaming. For example, some cards that offer bonus rewards in this category only count music and video as eligible streaming services. Entertainment as a category typically also does not include video game streaming or in-game purchases.
Are there credit cards for gamers with bad credit?
If you have bad credit, the rewards cards on this list might not yet be within reach. For building credit, consider a secured credit card instead. These cards are often easier to qualify for because they require an upfront security deposit that protects the bank against the risk of cardholders defaulting on their debt.
